general: Ceftizoxime is a 3rd generation parenteral cephalosporin with in vitro activity against aerobic gram-positive cocci (but not MRSA or enterococci) and aerobic gram-negative bacilli (but not P. aeruginosa) and selected anaerobic bacteria (but not B. fragilis).
Inactivated by bacteria that produce extended spectrum beta-lactamases (ESBLs).
Major adverse effects are allergy and development of C. difficile toxin-mediated colitis. For class-wide adverse effects, see Cephalosporins, Overview.

adult_dose.life_threatening_infection: Max 2 gm IV q4h (or 4 gm IV q8h)

renal_adjustment.crcl_or_egfr: CrCl >90: No dosage adjustment. CrCl >50-90: 2 gm q8-12h. CrCl 10-50: 2 gm q12-24h. CrCl <10: 2 gm q24h

adverse_effects: Local phlebitis (4%), fever, rash (2%), neutropenia, eosinophilia (4%), thrombocytopenia, increased PT/PTT, C. difficile colitis, increased LFTs (4%).
Ceftizoxime has the same R1 side chain as cefotaxime, cefpodoxime, cefpirome, cefditoren, ceftriaxone, and cefepime. Cross-allergenicity may occur.

pregnancy_risk.fda_risk_category: No evidence of toxicity in humans or animals
pregnancy_risk.lactation: Milk concentrations low, adverse effects not expected. Monitor infant for GI toxicity.
pregnancy_risk.footnote: Capital letter = Old FDA risk category; Text = New FDA risk category

comments: Where available. No longer marketed in the US
